MONL.content: alone in a genre [particular] that becomes a universal example, exemplarity of host as hostage: “universal hostage”
Derrida has the illusion he cultivates his own desert, whereas a hostage’s place was reserved for him, as a summons (mise en demeure)

H.content: the other becomes a hostile subject, I risk becoming their hostage.
Theseus, with Oedipus’ burial secret, becomes a retained hostage, a detained addressee
everyone is hostage to the dead man (Oedipus)

A.content: from kidnapping to hostage war (different modes of technology)
pass from hostage to host/guest from host/guest to ghost in series: hostage, host, guest, ghost, holy ghost, Geist

all politics require time & space of mourning, a topolitology of sepulcher, anamnesic (thematic) relation to spirit as revenant, open hospitality to guest as ghost [in English] whom one holds, as he holds us, hostage

ATIA.content: Levinas reconfigures Descartes’ infinite will to “I am (following) after the infinite” > subject as host/hostage of the infinite

HST.content: Levinas’ change of accent, scenery (paysage) (from Totality & Inf… to Otherw…): from peaceful welcome to violent hostage > no apparent inconsistency

the same logic: the one welcoming comes 2nd, thus hostage > inseparability of concept of substitution & concept of subjectivity as hostage: hostage, responsible for all, therefore substitutable, precisely where he is absolutely irreplaceable
hostage: “we offer ourselves as a pledge,” captivity, spiritual residence [re: Massignon’s Badaliya, Arabic name for substitution, a spiritual community he founded in Egypt]
[re: Massignon’s, Kahil’s Badaliya] St. Paul: “while we were enemies, we were reconciled to God through the death of his son” > a sacred deposit, mystical substitution, hostage as disappropriation

for forgiveness to be possible, what there is to forgive must remain unforgivable: otherwise exchange, excuse [see p. 380] > logical aporia (not just formal logic) but tragedy of compassion: intersubjectivity as destiny of hostage, madness of substitution

limit (of forgiveness) cannot be crossed (infranchissable)—and is crossed insofar as it can’t be [hymen] > ultimate compassion, very test of substitution (impossible), to be hostage and hôte of the other
substitution of hostage as un être-sous, être-dessous, not the beneath of subjectum, substantia, hypokeimenon but submitted (soumis), assujetti, to the height of the Most High (law above)
Levinas: memory of servitude in Egypt assembles humanity, ego is a hostage, ego ceaselessly missing itself, debt absorbed only by being increased; such is the pride of nonessence!
Levinas: man conceived as hostage for all the others [not selves for self]
an example is always a substitutable substitute > “you, for example” often  violent address of one who has power/authority to take hostage: inscribes possible replaceability in address to other

+R.content: Derrida yielded to Adami (hooked like a fish [hostage]), as if his angular signature was waiting for me [Derrida], a stupefying advance > it became Derrida's business, made him speak

TN.content: Derrida tempted to let himself be tempted to think, to desire, the least venial, least expiable temptation: substitution w/out sacrifice > would the neutral spacing (the khōra) offer hospitality to this substitution of substitution or detain it forever as a hostage?

ATM.content: Levinas: the substitution of the hostage discovers the trace
as a woman, by reversing dissymmetry [of tout autre in Levinas], Derrida has added rape [hostage to other, raped by other]

AD.content: Levinas: “responsibility for the other,” “responsibility of the hostage,” an experience of substitution & sacrifice
for Levinas, the hôte is a hostage insofar as he’s a subject obsessed (thus besieged), persecuted, put into question in the place where he takes place—in election

hostage: 1) a hôte given/received as a substitute pledge (gage) in places of power, at disposal of sovereign, hospitality w/out property, “accusation by everyone” 2) obsidium, obsidatus—condition of being captive/hostage, a state of siege, “persecuting obsession,” “responsibility for everyone” > acc. both lineages there’s a token of proof (gage) of substitution
Badaliya—substitution “as hostages”—Massignon’s persecution resonates, up to a point, w/ Levinas’

for Levinas, “substitution,” absolute passivity, “possibility of the impossible” that’s not Heidegger’s death, but the condition of the hostage, responsibility before/beyond death— impossibility of “slipping away (se dérober)”
ex-propriety makes of the subject a hôte and hostage (gentle), someone who is in his own home in the home of the other—“anachronism of a debt preceding the loan”
